anchor.surface_text: Under the amended Indian Coinage Act provision was made in s. 14 for the substitution of value expressed in annas, pace and pies by value expressed in naya paisa, which was the new companynage introduced under the amended Act. Section 14 reads as under- S.14 1  The rupee shall be divided into one hundred units and the new companyn representing such unit may be designated by the Central Government, by numberification in the Official Gazette, under such name as it thinks fit, and the rupee, half rupee and quarter-rupee shall be respectively equivalent to one hundred, fifty and twenty five such new companyns and shall, subject to the provisions of sub- section  1  and sub-section  2  of section 13 and to the extent specified therein, be a legal tender in payment or on account accordingly.

issues.text: Whether the substitution of .02 naya paisa per rupee for 3 pies per rupee in the Mysore Sales Tax Act amounted to an enhancement of tax which was illegal as it breached Article 265 of the Constitution and was not enacted as a Money Bill under Articles 198, 199 and 207

anchor.surface_text: Two objections were taken to the validity of the tax Firstly it was argued that by the substitution of 2 naya paisas in place of 3 pies there was it change in the tax eligible by the Mysore Sales Tax Act and this companyld only be done if that enactment had been passed according to the procedure for Money Bills in the manner provided by Arts. 198, 199 and 207 of the Constitution and as numbersuch Money Bill was introduced or passed for the enhancement of the tax, the tax was illegal and invalid.

issues.text: Whether the Indian Coinage Act, being a Central Act on coinage and legal tender under Entry 36 List I, could change the rate of tax under the state Mysore Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was submitted that the Indian Coinage Act, being a Central Act dealing with companynage and legal tender under item 36 of List I, companyld number change the rate of tax under the Mysore Sales Tax Act. It is unnecessary to decide this question because if the Central Act i.e. the Indian Coinage Act, has number the effect of changing 3 pies into .02 Nps in the rate of tax leviable under the Mysore Sales Tax Act,

issues.text: Whether the principle of res judicata applied to bar the present writ petition under Article 226 due to the previous High Court order setting aside the provisional assessment

anchor.surface_text: It was then argued that because of the order of the High Court in a previous petition, under Art. 226 whereby the provisional assessment was set aside the principle of res judicata applied and a different decision companyld number be given in the present petition which was subsequently filed after the final assessment. In our opinion there is numbermerit in that submission.

issues.text: Whether the levy and assessment of sales tax at the converted rate of .02 Nps per rupee under the Mysore Sales Tax Act post coinage amendment was valid and not liable to be quashed under Article 226

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of assessment relating to two quarters i. e. from April 1, 1957 to September 30, 1957, under the Mysore Sales Tax Act, Act VI of 1948. The appellant is a firm registered under the Mysore Sales Tax Act and was assessed to sales tax on a return of over Rs. 58,36,422.26 Nps and the tax imposed on that sum at .02 Nps per rupee was Rs. 1,16,728.44 Nps.

arguments.claim: Substitution of 2 naya paisas in place of 3 pies constitutes an enhancement or change in the tax leviable under the Mysore Sales Tax Act, which could only be valid if passed as a Money Bill under Articles 198, 199 and 207 of the Constitution, and since no such Money Bill was introduced or passed, the tax is illegal and invalid

anchor.surface_text: Two objections were taken to the validity of the tax Firstly it was argued that by the substitution of 2 naya paisas in place of 3 pies there was it change in the tax leviable by the Mysore Sales Tax Act and this could only be done if that enactment had been passed according to the procedure for Money Bills in the manner provided by Arts. 198, 199 and 207 of the Constitution and as no such Money Bill was introduced or passed for the enhancement of the tax, the tax was illegal and invalid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n of new companynage i.e. naya paisas in place of annas, pice and pies numberenhancement of tax was enacted but it was I merely a substitution of one

arguments.court_reasoning: No enhancement of tax enacted; merely substitution of equivalent coinage values. Even if taxing measure, procedural irregularities regarding Money Bills cannot be questioned under Articles 212 and 255.

arguments.claim: The Indian Coinage Act, being a Central Act dealing with coinage and legal tender under item 36 of List I, could not change the rate of tax under the state Mysore Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was submitted that the Indian Coinage Act, being a Central Act dealing with coinage and legal tender under item 36 of List I, could not change the rate of tax under the Mysore Sales Tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the Governor either by the Governor or by the President  b   c  Consequently the tax cannot be challenged on the ground that it is companytrary to th

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to decide as the Mysore Existing Laws Construction of References to Values Act, 1957 independently provides for conversion to naya paisa without changing tax substance.

arguments.claim: The High Court's previous order under Article 226 setting aside the provisional assessment operates as res judicata, barring a different decision in the present petition after final assessment

anchor.surface_text: It was then argued that because of the order of the High Court in a previous petition, under Art. 226 whereby the provisional assessment was set aside the principle of res judicata applied and a different decision could not be given in the present petition which was subsequently filed after the final assessment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecision companyld number be given in the present petition which was subsequently filed after the final assessment. In our opinion there is numbermerit

arguments.court_reasoning: Previous petition set aside provisional assessment based on respondents' memo not opposing; no indication of issues raised or decided matching the present case.

arguments.claim: Substitution of naya paisa for annas, pice and pies in the Mysore Sales Tax Act does not enact enhancement of tax but merely substitutes one equivalent coinage for another

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion by substitution of new coinage i.e. naya paisas in place of annas, pice and pies no enhancement of tax was enacted but it was merely a substitution of one coinage by another of equivalent value.

arguments.claim: Even assuming the substitution is a taxing measure, its validity cannot be challenged for offending Articles 197-199 or procedure in Article 202 due to protections in Articles 212 and 255

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that it is a taxing measure its validity cannot be challenged on the ground that it offends Arts. 197 to 199 and the procedure laid down in Art. 202 of the Constitution. Article 21 prohibits the validity of any proceedings in a legislature of a State from being called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure and Art. 255 lays down that requirements as to recommendation and previous sanction are to be regarded as matters of procedure only.

arguments.claim: The levy in naya paisa is valid under the Mysore Existing Laws Construction of References to Values Act, 1957, which converts old coinage references without being a taxing measure

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to decide this question because if the Central Act i.e. the Indian Coinage Act, has no the effect of changing 3 pies into .02 Nps in the rate of tax leviable under the Mysore Sales Tax Act, the Mysore Existing Laws Construction of References to Values Act, 1957, which has been set out above has made a provision for charging the tax in terms of naya paisas instead of pies. Therefore the levy of tax in terms of naya paisas is not unconstitutional nor is it a taxing measure but it deals merely with the conversion of the old coinage into new coinage.

arguments.claim: The previous High Court decision does not operate as res judicata as it does not indicate the issues raised and decided

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no merit in that submission. The previous petition upon which the appellant relies was to set aside the provisional assessment and it was set aside in the following language Read Memo dated 7-6-1958 by the Advocate General and Advocate for respondent, stating that the respondents do not oppose the writ petition being allowed and that the provisional assessment may be set aside. The previous decision setting aside the provisional assessment does not indicate what issues were raised and decided and there is no indication that the question now raised before us was before the Court. That decision cannot therefore operate as res judicata.

The previous petition upon which the appellant relies was to set aside the provisional assessment and it was set aside in the following language Read Memo dated 7-6-1958 by the Advocate General and Advocate for respondent, stating that the respondents do number oppose the writ petition being allowed and that the provisional assessment may be set aside. The previous decision setting aside the provisional assessment does number indicate what issues were raised and decided and there is numberindication that the question number raised before us was before the Court. That decision cannot therefore operate as res judicata.
